replies.text:
It‚Äôs kinda like how my position against torture has been shaken somewhat, because we can‚Äôt stop waging war. Bombs must occasionally fall in this world, and any time we approve a war, we accept that we will be torturing and killing innocent people and children with our weapons inevitably. If torturing insurgents (people we caught trying to kill our soldiers), could reduce number of civilians casualties from our weapons due our strikes being more directed. Then it seems like we have a moral obligation to do so by that reasoning. Each instance of torture need not be any more likely to five us useful information than bomb#6578 has of bringing about victory for our cause. And we know for certain we won‚Äôt be torturing infants in this hypothetical.
Doesn‚Äôt make it seem any more acceptable to me but maybe that‚Äôs a moral illusion that is held by all of us including ourselves

Maybe. However if torture didn‚Äôt work, it wouldn‚Äôt be controversial . The states has got loads of useful information from torturing detainees  , however they also got allot more of false information that we never hear about  because you‚Äôll say anything to make it stop.
But that is no different than counting the number of bombs and bullets used in war that did nothing useful and may have even put innocents at risk for no discernible gain.
 Khalid Shehk Mohamed being one of the more notable success stories for this method, cuz he turned in a good chunk of his terror cell. So yes, torture works, just no better than a shotgun or machine gun. The reason we stopped torturing enemy soldiers isn‚Äôt because you cannot get good information that way, but that  we don‚Äôt want our own soldiers tortured, so it is a mutual agreement not to do so. However terrorists don‚Äôt give us that courtesy, so that  line of reasoning is goes out the window 
Yes it has been used to get fake confessions an awful lot so that actually is an unassailable point. 
This may very quickly become an obsolete controversy even if i‚Äôm right because MIT is fast taking us to an age of mind reading machines, that would allow us to directly extract information from a captured terrorist‚Äôs brain without the uncertainties involved in torture .

replies.author: @ArgueWithTheMajority
replies.text: Ej MoreG Thanks for the enthusiasm. :D ...The topic of reparations is also very complex and people have a lot of misconceptions about the justification they have, so I see what you mean. I'd only like to add that far-reaching structural changes (political, societal and especially economic) would probably benefit the Afro-American community a lot more than reparations. Reparations might be a viable step towards making such changes possible, however, by empowering the black community. Might also cause even worse racist resentments and might make political change a more violent process. I don't know, it's difficult. Have a good one.

replies.author: @ArgueWithTheMajority
replies.text:
Ej MoreG I agree that not doing the right thing because there might be risks to it, cannot be a guiding principle for people who intend to change anything. I just tried to assess some possible outcomes on the spot, no more to it.


In response to your first comment, I just hope that science, technology and this weird species will realize together, rather sooner than later, that money is an outdated, imprecise, hierarchy-creating technology to regulate resources, production and distribution. If we used our full scientific and technological potential in order to make money obsolete and maximize global human and ecological well-being freeing people up to new levels of education, cooperation, open-source knowledge, innovation and self-fulfillment. That is my personal, ultimate dream vision. So, my main issue with reparations is that they are made out of money and would only take place in a society which hasn't abolished it. Consequenetly I know that whenever that would even happen, it would be just one temporary battle won. Sorry for the stream of consciousness I had going on there :D

replies.author: @ArgueWithTheMajority
replies.text:
Ej MoreG Hi my friend. I must not have expressed myself clearly. I am sorry I made you put a lot of thought into an answer that wasn't directly required in this case, because I agree.


I was not trying to frame any of this as a reason to avoid reparations. First, I mentioned the risks which came to my mind because risk assessment just seems reasonable to me, if only to be prepared.
Secondly, my lofty goals will probably not come true during my lifetime and I was not trying to advocate for inaction in the meantime. I was probably just rambling on about, essentially why the thought of reparations just doesn't seem like an actual solution to me, rather a stepping stone towards an actual solution. Not, that it shouldn't be done.
Nothing gives people agency like money, as long as we make it our central paradigm. So give it to a huge group of people who, yes, have been systematically and purposefully disadvantaged, abused, exploited and generally oppressed.
I do not disagree with you, I was just unsuccessfully trying to add a few additional aspects to the conversation. English isn't my first language, so I'm not always certain if I am getting my mesage across correctly and I'm actually thankful you made me aware of my failure to do so this time. No hard feelings on my part, I hope it's the same way for you.

replies.text:
Drinker_Of_ Milk you know what, it actually doesn‚Äôt matter how much value you do or don‚Äôt ascribe to an embryo or a foetus. It makes no difference whatsoever. 

Because until that embryo or foetus can survive on its own, outside of my body, I get to decide. That‚Äôs the entire point. I have the right to remove it from my body, at any point in time, because I have the right to bodily autonomy. Just like I cannot force you to give me blood or an organ, so too must I be allowed the right to decide what I use my body for. 

If the foetus isn‚Äôt yet at the point of viability (which is to say, the point at which it can survive outside of the womb), then it‚Äôs an abortion, a termination, whatever you wish to call it. If the foetus is at or after the point of viability, then I should be able to access early childbirth- that still gives that foetus the chance to live in its own, and I think that‚Äôs a perfectly reasonable compromise. 

Because I don‚Äôt care how far along the pregnancy is, I should be able to opt out at any time, for any reason. This is my morality, where the bodily autonomy of people is held above all else. And it‚Äôs even more important in a situation like pregnancy, given the risks involved. Pregnancy and childbirth still kills women, even in developed countries. It can (and does, fairly often) result in lifelong injury. Now, most women accept these risks when we choose to continue a pregnancy, but no woman (or any other person capable of carrying a pregnancy) should ever be forced to accept such risks. 

To say otherwise is not only to give foetuses more rights than women, it gives women fewer rights than a corpse. This is not acceptable to me. And you can disagree with me all you like, call me nasty names, whatever. I don‚Äôt care. I know my own morality, built upon my environment, but also upon a great amount of research and thought on the subject. I‚Äôm also satisfied that my morality is consistent. Which is more than I can say for the majority of anti-choicers.

replies.author: @spacecadet9663
replies.text: @IloveGorgeousGeorge Yeah, I really feel like a lot of Gun rights people don't truly understand what "stand your ground" laws actually pertain to. For almost all of the states that have stand your ground laws on the books don't allow for people to shoot others simply because they feel threatened. This is flat out bullshit, stand your ground only applies to  personal private property. Namely, that means you can't just shoot someone on the sidewalk simply because you feel threatened, the person whose threatening you has to be doing so while on your private property. Even then it doesn't apply when the person whose been "threatened" has an opportunity to remove themselves from the situation (such as leaving, or going into another part of the property and calling the police.) This doesn't apply when outside of one's private property at all, as understandably when one is in public it's very easy to extract oneself from the situation. Even then stand your ground doesn't allow for violence that goes above and beyond what is necessary in order to neutralize the supposed threat. The means your not in the clear if you shoot someone who's got a pocket knife because you feel threatened by the fact that he has a knife. You'd be in the right to shoot someone only when they're in your home and they have equal firepower so to speak and are actively threatening you will that firepower. And lastly, it also doesn't apply when the person you feel threatened by is attempting to extract themselves from the situation. For instance, it would be murder in my home state to shoot a man whose broken into your property if that person attempts to run away when they see you, as they are no longer threatening you or your property but instead are trying to get away from the threatening situation they find themselves in.

replies.author: @spacecadet9663
replies.text: @bensimpson570 I wouldn't say that the bible is inherently proslavery, moreso it's pro-authority. The passages of the new testament that mention slavery specifically maintain that God has supposedly put you into such a situation for a reason and to be content with that (from one of Paul's epistles). This also applies to those who own slaves, as God supposedly put them into your power for a reason and as such you must treat them well. I'm not trying to spread slavery apologia by the way. I actually dispise paul's epistles for multiple reasons, not the least of which are these arguments about authority as well as the multiple sidelong insults made against homosexuality as well as an entire epistle dedicated to making the Jews out to be sinful heathens. That being said, as far as the old testament goes slavery is mentioned quite a few times. Namely in the last three books of the Torah (leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy). These legal codes don't apply to Christianity at all, as most people accept the arguments offered in the epistle to the Romans. In this epistle, Paul lays out his arguments as for why Christians need not subject themselves to Jewish canon law. As Christ supposedly died to offer all who believe grace and forgiveness of sins. According to his argument, the law is the item through which people came to know what was sinful, and through knowing that it is forbidden people become subverted by sinful nature and sin even though they wish to live by the law. On top of that, adherence to the laws of the bible are a persons way of measuring earthly "righteousness" when compared to others on earth (for instance, you wouldn't be able to say someone's a good person without knowing what makes a bad one) and as such those that live through faith need not apply themselves to what amounts to a dick measuring contest. This is backed up by one part of the book of Genesis: "Abram believed the word of God, and it was reckoned unto him as righteousness." Meaning Abraham's belief in God came before his being morally good by earthly standards. The epistle to the Romans is often why most Christian groups don't care about eating Kosher foods. Jesus also personally addresses the kosher food laws in the book of mark saying: "Nothing that enters a person by way of their mouth may make them unclean, for this enters the stomach and is expelled into the sewer. But what comes from a person's mouth, truly I tell you, that corrupts completely. For out of the mouth comes all forms of licentiousness, lies, gossip, and intention of murder." The epistle to the Romans goes on to say that if one applies even one of the Jewish canon laws to themselves as a Christian, they must apply all laws to themselves. That would mean that if a modern christian wished to own slaves they would have to abide by biblical law around the owning of other people as well as all other laws and strictures, which would be impossible as many of these laws apply to sacrifices that must be made at the temple in jerusalem. Both the books of exodus as well as leviticus have laws surrounding slavery within them. Firstly, in exodus God tells moses that all of the laws of Israel shall apply to all equally saying "You shall have one law for two peoples, for both you and the residents among you shall share in one law" and later in leviticus tells moses that nothing that is sold (property that is, including people) shall forever remain in the buyers possession: "after seven periods of seven years, on that sabbatical year shall be the year of Jubilee. All who have been sold into bondage shall come home and all who have sold property shall receive it and see it returned. Only in the cities of the levites shall they never sell their ancestral holdings as they are given to me to do the service of the lord." This also would apply to slaves (at least Jewish slaves) as they would be allowed their freedom in the year of Jubilee. Now, even according to the bible the tribes of Israel never did this (it's a point of contention in the book of kings, King Josiah finds the book of the law and is enraged that his forefathers did not listen to the word of God).

replies.author: @ruedelta
replies.text:
@ducktube7473 I think we have to establish facts here first. First off, most Chinese also remember the events prior to 6/4, including the televised meetings between the student leaders and the politburo. Simply put, they did not show any sign of negotiation or diplomacy - it was more of a roast. You don't take an opportunity like that and turn it into a spectacle for self-satisfaction. That is how it is seen in Chinese culture, whether you agree with it or not. You cannot interpret this in a western culture context because this is not America we are talking about.


Second, facts have to be established here. There is quite widespread agreement among people who actually have studied the events that there weren't tanks rolling over kids or any sort of massed gunning at the square (look at the leaked cables on WikiLeaks and for god's sake avoid the Falun Gong cultists) - it was evacuated peacefully. This makes sense - it's their kids, they don't want to harm them either. If we are talking about Muxidi, everything becomes much more nebulous, but that is far removed from "tanks rolling over students." It is also physically far removed from Tiananmen Square.


Third, your anti-Chinese bias is showing hardcore here. Rather than assuming that everyone is brainwashed, perhaps spend some time visiting China and asking around? I assure you, no matter how much the press wants you to think that you know better than them, they are far more aware of their situation than you could ever be. Run this with some simple logic - can you understand the real US without knowing a lick of English?


If you visit China, you know that it is not a place where you can just cite a source. Nothing is set in stone because of the guanxi system and the rapid pace of changes in the country. No one writes shit down like that, at least not without extremely rocky support (think lack of peer review, verification). Perhaps this is bad for historical traditions and records - yes, and that is its own healthy debate, but it works as-is for the culture. What this doesn't mean though is to trust what people outside of the country say about China, especially those who make a living spewing cold war theories out like it's 1970 again.


_At the very least_ you should know that it is a topic with a lot of nuance, not "evil government crushes innocent students who just want freedom and democracy."

replies.text: ‚Äã@flank6349 Ironically, you have to look to Marxist theory to explain the failure of the Soviet Union. If you want something more in-depth than a third-grade "Muh hooman rights, muh freedumbs", you have to actually look at dialectical materialist theory to explain how forming a transition state from feudalism will inevitably cause worse working standards; how rapid industrialization from agrarian economies would necessitate horrific human costs; and how the state-ownership model and nomenklatura-class were inevitable and weren't actually socialist/communist to begin with. Trotsky predicted the collapse of the Soviet Union in the inter-war period and was vindicated decades later. Not to mention the fact that neoliberalization and the so-called catch-up revolutions in Eastern Europe caused an economic collapse and the loss of 30-40% of GDP in Eastern Europe, disillusionment with which is literally the root cause of illiberalism and nationalist jingoism in those regions. replies.text:
@Revolutionary Communist Thanks. Now this here answer goes a bit everywhere, but here we go.
How much of the Soviet progress can be attributed to communism? There was a pretty significant rise in standards in most other places as well. Take for example my home country of Finland, we were in a pretty shitty place after WW2, yet the nation got on pretty well and even payed back the absurd war reparations to the Soviets. We also got one of the most equal and least corrupt societies. This was done with what I guess would be labeled as social democracy, a form of regulated capitalism.
I also want to bring up China and fascism again though. This is the definition straight from wikipedia:
"Fascism  is a form of far-right, authoritarian ultranationalism[1][2] characterized by dictatorial power, forcible suppression of opposition, and strong regimentation of society and of the economy".
I think that's pretty spot on on what's going on in China atm. Add to that another definition I've read about fascism, that centers on the state controlling private corporations and their ethinc cleansing of the Uyghurs, I would say there's a strong case to be made that China is right now a far right nation.
So now I'm kind of wondering, since most definitions of communism strives after public steering/owning without a state, how would one get to that. How would you get a system safe from the greed and lust for power in human nature. In my head, you need to have some sort of organisation for a society, that's usually called a government. And when you have a government for a society that's in charge of everything, that's really attractive for power grabbers. I really don't see how a system would be shaped that would be immune to take the authoritarian routes of the CCCP and China. Maybe if you had very small separate units so that one person or group could not seize power over all, but then you're pretty much back to having many small states.
Sorry bout the long text, not trying to be obnoxious here, I'm genuinely interested in this discussion.

replies.author: @davidm1926
replies.text:
@flank6349 "Just because I despise communists and anarchists, that doesn't mean I find it ok when capitalist countries do wrong." - So you'd be on an equivalent footing as a communist who doesn't think the Holodomor was okay. You're both advocating political systems, while dodging the question of whether atrocities are natural products of those systems, ignoring complicity you might have in hypothetical future atrocities.

I choose to gamble that a more ethical and democratic form of capitalism is possible, but that's a theoretical claim, like the claim that true socialism or communism are possible. And I still don't have a great answer to the claim that capitalism has resulted in more bloodshed than communism. It does matter that capitalism has been a far more successful, widely spread system with a correspondingly greater opportunity to do harm - similar to the reason that fascism has a far lower body count than communism.

replies.author: @bobnub8194
replies.text: @seanaaron94 If you actually look at the nature of economic development, it becomes increasingly clear that the entire capitalist system sustains itself through unequal material relations and trade relations with periphery countries. The legacy of capitalism isn't some Smithian ideal of "free markets drive down apple prices for john doe", it's a legacy of mis-developed periphery countries pursuing extractivist modes of production because they were forced into it by the legacy of colonialism and current economic hegemony of the west. Furthermore, bourgeois economists have already accepted the natural cycles of boom and bust in the capitalist economy predicted by Marx and expounded upon by Marxist thinkers for two centuries. The fact that such crises occur hasn't really, existentially become apparent to you (or indeed most of us). The repeated rise and collapse of economic bubbles, and the slow growth in periphery and semi-periphery countries not only shattered post-Soviet  Fukuyama liberalism but has engendered the rise of illiberal reactionaries like Orban that "liberals" purport to fight against. On your point that the left doesn't exist in America, it's not a result of any failure in ideology. Capitalism is more predatory and concentrated than ever; the rise of globalization has merely made exploitation of workers, exploitation of the periphery countries...etc more exigent. Climate change, a direct result of global capitalism's need to expand production for the sake of capital accumulation, threatens our extinction, material scarcity and hegemonic conflicts increase international tensions and push us towards war every day. And as you macho-posture aout mindless violence and people's heads being blown up, the world is pushed toward instability by the very blinding ideology you can't understand any critique of.  Like Professor Terry Eagleton pointedly jokes about liberal ideology, claiming that Marxism is finished and unnecessary is like claiming that firefighting is out of date because arsonists are more dangerous and crafty than ever - poignantly, quite the opposite.

author: @asteroidrules
text: Something I think worth pointing out about how Fox whitewashes the Nisour square massacre is their propagandist makes specific effort to call out, and berate, the fact that the mercenaries in question are being tried in a civilian court. I think this detail is something worth noting when you remember one of the inciting actions behind the American revolution was that, prior to independence, British Imperial troops stationed in the American territories did not answer to the local civil authorities, and were consequently allowed to get away with multiple criminal acts; it was consequently a detail specifically stated in the Constitution of the United States (and the first article at that!) that the military should be answerable to a civil authority. By arguing against that principle here, Flaherty is arguing against both the Constitution of the United States, and in fact one of the principles behind the American revolution itself!

replies.author: @efffvss
replies.text: What did they get away with? The main incident I can remember in pre-revolution America was the Boston Massacre. While the incident became heavily propagandised, the soldiers involved were tried by the local authorities (and defended by future President John Adams) within the year. So that isn't really 'getting away with criminal acts'.

replies.author: @asteroidrules
replies.text: @efffvss In 1768 British marines stationed in Annapolis, Maryland murdered two civilians, rather than being given a proper trial they were given a court martial and declared innocent. A similar situation occurred in North Carolina in 1771. The 27 Grievances in the Declaration of Independence make specific mention of how "[King George] has affected to render the military independent of and superior to the civil power" (grievance 12) "protecting [imperial troops], by a mock trial from punishment for any murders which they should commit on the inhabitants of these states" (grievance 15) and "is at this time transporting large armies of foreign mercenaries to compleat the works of death, desolation, and tyranny, already begun with circumstances of cruelty and perfidy scarcely paralleled in the most barbarous ages, and unworthy [of] the head of a civilized nation" (grievance 25, particularly noteworthy as it's specifically complaining about the use of mercenary troops).

replies.author: @felixleidinger1670
replies.text:
@maxw.2579 To play devils advocate: they at least have to pretent. And a lot of european nations like Germany have a system of criminal accountability for their soldiers based on legal problems during the Nuremburg trials. Is a soldier liable for his actions if he was ordered to? Or can he be prosecuted for following orders if a refusal meant a crime in itself? What about ideology-driven descisions of an individual, is the officer responsible?

The solution they came up with is the concept "civilian in uniform"- even after the draft has been ended and the Bundeswehr professionalised. The general tone in the army is compared to the US  less screaming, less militaristic pride bullshit, more professional and respectfull conduct from soldier and officer. A soldier can refuse an direct order if it goes against his conscience and wont be persecuted even if damage results from that, his commanding officer is liable for miscommunicating the situation if that happens and responsibility and accountability go up the chain of command from there. On the other hand, this makes an soldier directly legally responsible for his own individual conduct outside direct command. Is he not excused by the circumstances of the situation, his head is on the block, and worse than an civilian would be- because the uniform means an extra level of responsibility that takes away a major level of legal protection, unlike the US who often grant their forces immunity. Also, the Bundeswehr at least, through psychological testing nominally tries to block nutjobs from joining the forces, though not really effectively, but they wont hire the usual US nutjobs like those Blackwater guys because those probably wont be able to stick with this code of conduct.

Not to say there are no scandals to find here, far from it, especially far right extremists in the army. But at least systematically there is some actual legal accountability compared to some shady corporation, also parlamentary and therefore public oversight. Some years ago an officer ordered an airstrike on an visibly armed convoy with gas-tankers that was on direct course towards a base. But also visible were women and children in the trucks. The guy had to make a descision- and ordered the strike. Huge scandal in Germany. There was a public investigation into the descision, and a trial. 

Im not saying that the action was necessary, or that the judges who aquitted the guy were right. But "civilian in uniform" is a far cry from how the US employs and shields its soldiers or PMCs from prosecution. 
A soldier is usually seen as something like an external policeman bound by law and regulations, a professional job like any other and not beyond criticism, with the ability to kill but also the responsibilities and need for accountability that come with that, not some muscled-up gun-slinging superhero beyond the rules who gets shielded by his country if he steps out of bounds. 

Even if ones a pacifist I hope one can see the difference here. I agree the system needs much improvement though.

replies.author: @maxw.2579
replies.text:
@felixleidinger1670 Im german myself and I actually agree with everything you wrote, the Bundeswehr is pretty okay for a military but I still dont exactly love it. For me its less about pacifism and more about being against western imperialism even if I have to admit that since a lot of areas are already in turmoil the humanitarian work and the stabilizing efforts that are done by the Bundeswehr and other militaries is probably a lot better than leaving areas to warlords.
